title: fastabx: A library for efficient computation of ABX discriminability
author: Maxime Poli (ENS Paris), Emmanuel Dupoux (ENS Paris), Thomas Schatz (ENS Paris), Marvin Lavechin (ENS Paris), ..., Ewan Dunbar (ENS Paris)
relevance_why: The methodologies discussed and the efficient computation of ABX tasks can be applied in Haohe Liu's audio-related tasks, particularly in evaluating speech and audio representation models.
background: The paper presents a library for efficiently calculating ABX discriminability, a metric for assessing how well different audio representations can distinguish between categories in speech.
contribution: The fastabx library introduces an efficient and flexible framework for computing ABX discriminability, enhancing the evaluation of representation learning models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous libraries like ABXpy and Libri-Light were either slow or hardcoded for specific tasks, limiting flexibility.
technical_comparison.novelty: Fastabx combines speed and flexibility, using a PyTorch extension for efficient calculations and allowing easy configuration for various ABX task specifications.

key_innovation: Implemented a Dynamic Time Warping algorithm on both CPU and CUDA backends, significantly improving computation speed for audio data.
real_world_impact: Fastabx provides an accessible tool for researchers to evaluate various self-supervised models in audio processing, impacting practical applications in speech recognition and language understanding.
limitations: The authors mention that further optimization of the Dynamic Time Warping on the CUDA backend could enhance performance but do not detail other limitations.

new_terms.ABX discriminability: **ABX discriminability** is a metric for evaluating the distinction between audio categories based on their representations, requiring the distances between specific pairs of samples.
new_terms.Dynamic Time Warping (DTW): **Dynamic Time Warping** is an algorithm used for aligning sequences that may vary in time or speed, commonly employed in speech analysis.

open_sourcing: Source code is available at https://github.com/bootphon/fastabx
